update.description:
This could be either a misunderstanding on my behalf or an inconsistency in `physics::World` in regards to how `physics::Actor` instances are treated.

The `Actor` derives from `Model` and as far as I can see, is otherwise treated like a model too. The difference is that it is not added to the `WorldPrivate::models` list in the `World::LoadActor() `method, as it is done in `World::LoadModel()` for the "normal" models.

Often this would actually go unnoticed because in many places, it is not the `models` vector which is used to iterate through the models, but instead the general element pointers, in this form:

```C++
  // Load the plugins for all the models                                        
  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < this->dataPtr->rootElement->GetChildCount(); ++i)
  {                                                                             
    if (this->dataPtr->rootElement->GetChild(i)->HasType(Base::MODEL))          
    {
       ...
```

The `Actor` models are caught with this. Crucially, this approach is also used for `World::BuildSceneMsg`, so that when a new gzclient connects to the world, it will get the model, and everything will run nicely.

However the actors are not returned with `World::Models()`. So if we're using `World`  interface directly (not via messages connection like gzclient), then we miss out on the `Actor` models.

Is there any particular reason this was done like this for the actors?  
If not, I suggest treating them as the models and adding the changes of this PR to make the behaviour of `World::LoadActor()` the same as `World::LoadModel()`.

By the way: The `Road` is treated as entity only as well, and not registered separately in a similar fashion (see `World::LoadRoad`). But this would have to be treated separately because it's not technically a model (or should it be?). It would be nice to have a method which returns all entities which are no model then, e.g. `Entity_M World::Entities().` It would be good to have a getter which allows to get *all* the objects in the world incl. roads (lights could still be treated separately as it is).

What's your thoughts on this?
update.title: Added actors in World as models so they get returned with Models()

* [xenial gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/460/) looks ok
* [xenial no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/109/#showFailuresLink) also seems to have no related failures

• homebrew is ok
  • xenial gpu looks ok
  • xenial no gpu also seems to have no related failures

content.raw:
Sounds good. Let me know if I should add the general group for all entities with this PR - but it probably makes sense to keep it for a separate PR?

I added issue #2242 as you suggested.

Sounds good. Let me know if I should add the general group for all entities with this PR - but it probably makes sense to keep it for a separate PR?

pull_request.title: Added actors in World as models so they get returned with Models()

pullrequest.title: Added actors in World as models so they get returned with Models()

content.raw:
I think this looks good. Actor is just a special kind of model, so it makes sense that they are grouped together. Even the call to `PublishPose`  seems to be used by Actors too.

I agree with your suggestion of having a general group for all entities in the world. And I'd actually include Lights there, since they're also Entities. Maybe we can open an issue about this.

I just triggered CI builds for this PR.

‌
content.html:
I think this looks good. Actor is just a special kind of model, so it makes sense that they are grouped together. Even the call to PublishPose seems to be used by Actors too.

I agree with your suggestion of having a general group for all entities in the world. And I'd actually include Lights there, since they're also Entities. Maybe we can open an issue about this.

I just triggered CI builds for this PR.

‌

pull_request.title: Added actors in World as models so they get returned with Models()

update.description:
This could be either a misunderstanding on my behalf or an inconsistency in `physics::World` in regards to how `physics::Actor` instances are treated.

The `Actor` derives from `Model` and as far as I can see, is otherwise treated like a model too. The difference is that it is not added to the `WorldPrivate::models` list in the `World::LoadActor() `method, as it is done in `World::LoadModel()` for the "normal" models.

Often this would actually go unnoticed because in many places, it is not the `models` vector which is used to iterate through the models, but instead the general element pointers, in this form:

```C++
  // Load the plugins for all the models                                        
  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < this->dataPtr->rootElement->GetChildCount(); ++i)
  {                                                                             
    if (this->dataPtr->rootElement->GetChild(i)->HasType(Base::MODEL))          
    {
       ...
```

The `Actor` models are caught with this. Crucially, this approach is also used for `World::BuildSceneMsg`, so that when a new gzclient connects to the world, it will get the model, and everything will run nicely.

However the actors are not returned with `World::Models()`. So if we're using `World`  interface directly (not via messages connection like gzclient), then we miss out on the `Actor` models.

Is there any particular reason this was done like this for the actors?  
If not, I suggest treating them as the models and adding the changes of this PR to make the behaviour of `World::LoadActor()` the same as `World::LoadModel()`.

By the way: The `Road` is treated as entity only as well, and not registered separately in a similar fashion (see `World::LoadRoad`). But this would have to be treated separately because it's not technically a model (or should it be?). It would be nice to have a method which returns all entities which are no model then, e.g. `Entity_M World::Entities().` It would be good to have a getter which allows to get *all* the objects in the world incl. roads (lights could still be treated separately as it is).

What's your thoughts on this?
